p: Given the global expanding distribution of Aedes mosquitoes [ 1], dengue has established itself throughout the world’s tropical and subtropical regions in both endemic and epidemic transmission cycles, causing significant morbidity and mortality, particularly highly endemic in South-East Asia (SEA) [ 24– 26]. However, dengue remains a seasonal disease in China, with epidemics occasionally triggered by imported dengue viruses (DENV) [ 27]. More than 90% of imported cases between 2005 and 2014 originated from SEA [ 27– 31]. Following China’s economic boom in the last two decades, the number of Chinese citizens travelling abroad has increased from 5 million in 1996 to 128 million in 2015 [ 32]. Recent government led initiatives to further foster international trade may contribute to increased flows between SEA and China [ 33], which could also increase the number of importations of pathogens including DENV.
